content.text: In a crawling position, your baby will touch the floor at six points: two palms open wide (shoulder width), two knees (hip width) and the front of the legs and feet. While rocking and crawling on all six points, babies pull themselves forward by shifting their weight to one side and lifting the other side, then switching sides repeatedly.

Crawling makes the shoulder belt muscles strong and ready for the fine motor skills that are coming when your baby starts to sit on their own and, of course, for school. The upper body and lower body are working together, which is very important for future milestones. Hand and foot coordination is also happening, and if your baby hasn’t passed the army crawl stage, this is the time for the body to work on it and increase the connections between the brain’s nerves.
At this stage, baby’s levels of curiosity and independence increase due to their ability to explore more of their surroundings.

If you see that your baby is having a hard time achieving this milestone by the age of 10 months, you should consult with your pediatrician or an infant development guide to learn how to help your baby. These important abilities are the foundation of their physical, sensory and emotional needs. Here are some signs your baby is doing well:

ul: The distance between the palms is not wider than their shoulders.
The distance between the knees is not wider than their pelvis.
Both knees are touching the surface.
